props.rawText:
NPI: 1435920051

Midtown Primary Care Associates
3700 Woodward Ave, Suite 200
Detroit, MI 48201

description: Referral Letter from Dr. Richard Jenkins

Marcus 'Mark' Elias Thorne is a 47-year-old male patient currently classified as high-risk, presenting with a primary diagnosis of Severe Acute Hepatitis or Acute Liver Injury of unknown etiology. His active problem list is dominated by signs of significant hepatic dysfunction, including acute jaundice, severe pruritus, and mild hepatomegaly, alongside a background comorbidity of obesity (BMI 31.5). His recent medical history highlights a dental abscess which was treated with a ten-day course of Amoxicillin-Clavulanate (Augmentin) from October 30 to November 9, 2025. Overlapping with and following this antibiotic course, he utilized Acetaminophen (both Tylenol PM and Extra Strength) frequently for pain relief until November 20, 2025. Given this temporal association, Suspected Drug-Induced Liver Injury (DILI) is currently being investigated as a primary differential. Consequently, safety alerts have been documented listing Amoxicillin-Clavulanate as the suspected causative agent for severe DILI (pending confirmation) and placing a restriction on Acetaminophen use due to its potential hepatotoxicity in his current state.

patientData.primaryDiagnosis: Severe Acute Hepatitis / Acute Liver Injury of Unknown Etiology

adverseEvents.description: Marked elevation of transaminases with ALT 620 U/L (>11x ULN) and AST 450 U/L, indicating rapid hepatocellular necrosis.
Total Bilirubin elevated to 5.2 mg/dL with clinical jaundice and severe generalized pruritus; biochemical pattern suggests mixed hepatocellular-cholestatic injury.
Peripheral blood Eosinophilia of 8.5% (Absolute 0.95 K/uL) coincident with liver dysfunction, suggesting an immuno-allergic mechanism.
Ultrasound evidence of diffuse fatty infiltration and hepatomegaly, indicating underlying metabolic susceptibility.

rucam.title: Causality Assessment Scoring (Hepatocellular Pattern)
rows: Time to onset (from exposure to injury)
Exposure start ~3 weeks ago; Onset of jaundice ~2 days ago
Onset falls within the suggestive 5–90 day latency period for idiosyncratic reaction.
Agents stopped <24 hours ago; trajectory pending
Insufficient time to evaluate enzyme de-challenge response.
Alcohol use is a potential risk factor for enhanced susceptibility.
Concomitant agent has hepatotoxic potential, complicating causality.
Ultrasound negative for obstruction; Viral/Autoimmune pending
Mechanical obstruction excluded; serological exclusion required for higher score.
Suspected agent is a known hepatotoxin
Class labeled as hepatotoxic in medical literature.

ctcae.title: CTCAE Hepatic Toxicity Scoring
rows: >1 - 1.5 x ULN; no bleeding symptoms reported.
ctcae.overall_grade: CTCAE Grade 3 — Severe adverse event requiring hospitalization

rucam_ctcae_analysis.reasoning: The patient presents with severe acute hepatocellular injury (ALT >10x ULN) accompanied by Grade 3 hyperbilirubinemia and clinical jaundice. The injury demonstrates a strong temporal correlation with a recent course of antibiotics (completed 1 week prior) and concurrent analgesic use. The presence of significant eosinophilia (8.5%) points towards a systemic hypersensitivity mechanism rather than a purely viral or ischemic etiology. Imaging has ruled out biliary obstruction. While synthetic function remains preserved (INR 1.2, Grade 1), the severity of the transaminitis warrants immediate cessation of all suspected agents and urgent monitoring for progression.

assessment.impression: Severe Acute Hepatocellular Hepatitis with cholestasis and systemic eosinophilia, temporally associated with recent antimicrobial and analgesic exposure.
differential: Acute Viral Hepatitis (A, B, C, E - pending serology)
Autoimmune Hepatitis (consider given severity and eosinophilia)
Mechanical Biliary Obstruction (effectively excluded by ultrasound but clinically suggested)

description:
#first encounter #first encounter.
 This is the first encounter in the patient's timeline. It is an Outpatient Visit recorded on March 5, 2024, with Dr. P. Stevens (General Practice). The patient, Sarah Miller (43, Female), presented with a chief complaint of increased fatigue over the past 4-5 months. The assessment revealed suboptimal control of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (HbA1c 58 mmol/mol) and Hypertension, alongside Chronic Fatigue Syndrome possibly related to Metabolic Dysfunction-associated Steatotic Liver Disease (MASLD). Physical exam noted a BMI of 32.0 (Class I obesity), BP 146/92 mmHg, and mild effusion in the right wrist due to Rheumatoid Arthritis. The plan involved ordering complete LFTs and HbA1c, with a follow-up scheduled in 4 weeks to evaluate eligibility for Methotrexate (MTX) therapy.

assessment.impression: Acute Dental Abscess (Right Mandibular Molar). Localized cellulitis.

encounter.chief_complaint: Severe throbbing jaw pain and facial swelling for 2 days.
encounter.hpi: Mr. Thorne presents with a 48-hour history of worsening pain in the right lower jaw. He describes the pain as throbbing and radiating to the ear. He reports difficulty chewing and 'swollen gums'. He denies difficulty breathing or swallowing. He has been taking OTC Ibuprofen with partial relief.

physical_exam.general: Patient appears uncomfortable but in no acute respiratory distress. Low-grade fever (37.8°C).
physical_exam.head_neck: Right-sided facial swelling noted along the mandible. Right submandibular lymphadenopathy (tender). Intra-oral exam reveals erythema and fluctuance at the gum line of tooth #30.

labs: None required for uncomplicated dental abscess.

management.follow_up: Advised to follow up with a Dentist for root canal or extraction once infection subsides.
management.instructions: Warm compresses. Return immediately if swelling spreads to neck or affects breathing.

description: This is the second encounter, an Outpatient visit occurring on April 1, 2024, with Dr. P. Stevens. The visit focused on reviewing abnormal liver function tests and planning Rheumatoid Arthritis treatment. The assessment highlighted an elevated ALT of 78 U/L, raising concerns for hepatocellular inflammation potentially related to MASLD. Consequently, Methotrexate initiation was deferred. The patient reported slight weight loss (0.5–1 kg) and was educated on the risks of liver injury. Vitals showed BP 142/90 mmHg and BMI 31.8. The plan included a comprehensive liver panel (HBsAg, HCV, ANA, Ferritin, etc.) and instructions to return in 4 weeks to review results.

assessment.impression:
1. Antibiotic-associated Gastritis / Dyspepsia. 
2. Fatigue/Malaise (likely viral or post-infection).

encounter.hpi:
Patient connects via video call. He finished his course of Augmentin yesterday for the dental abscess. Reports the tooth pain is 'mostly gone but throbs at night'. 

New Symptoms: Over the last 2 days, he has felt extremely tired ('washed out') with mild nausea and loss of appetite. He attributes this to 'the strong antibiotics messing up my stomach'. He denies vomiting, fever, or diarrhea. He reports trouble sleeping due to the residual jaw ache.

physical_exam.general: Patient appears fatigued but alert on video. No respiratory distress.
physical_exam.heent: No obvious facial swelling visible on camera. Patient states jaw opening is improved.

management.follow_up: Return to clinic if unable to keep fluids down or if pain worsens.
management.instructions: Stick to a bland diet (BRAT diet) for the stomach. Stay hydrated.

encounter.reason_for_visit: Follow-up question regarding nausea and fatigue.

description:
This is the third encounter, an Outpatient Follow-up on May 6, 2024, with Dr. P. Stevens. The purpose was to review the normalization of LFTs and reconsider Methotrexate initiation. The assessment showed LFTs had normalized (ALT 35 U/L) following ~1.5 kg weight loss and lifestyle changes; the hepatitis workup was negative. The impression was a transient elevation likely related to MASLD, and the patient was cleared for Methotrexate. Vitals included BP 140/88 mmHg and BMI 31.2. The plan instructed the patient to begin Methotrexate (7.5mg weekly) and Folic acid (5mg weekly) starting June 3, 2024, with a strict schedule for LFT and FBC monitoring every 6 weeks.

Case :
8. Has a non-invasive liver screen been performed? If so, what is the likelihood of
other liver diseases?

Yes — a non-invasive liver screen has been performed, and the results strongly suggest that the likelihood of other chronic liver diseases is low. In Encounter 3, she underwent a full viral hepatitis screen (HBsAg, HBcAb, HCV Ab), autoimmune panel (ANA, ASMA, LKM-1, IgG), and metabolic testing (Ferritin, TIBC), all of which were negative or normal, effectively ruling out chronic viral, autoimmune, and metabolic liver disease. Her Fib-4 score was 0.9, which falls into the low-risk category (<1.3) for significant fibrosis or cirrhosis, further reducing suspicion of alternative chronic pathology.

In addition, the USG (ultrasound) abdomen performed during her acute presentation showed coarse, steatotic liver parenchyma with hepatomegaly, consistent with MASLD/MASH, but critically no bile duct dilatation, no ascites, no portal hypertension, no nodularity, and patent portal/hepatic veins — all of which argue against other structural liver diseases such as primary biliary cholangitis, primary sclerosing cholangitis, infiltrative disorders, or obstructive causes. Taken together, both the screening panels, Fib-4 score, and imaging findings indicate that the likelihood of other liver diseases is very low, and her course is most consistent with MASLD with superimposed Methotrexate-induced DILI rather than another chronic liver disease. #non-invasive-liver-screen #non-invasive-liver-screen

assessment.impression: Severe Acute Hepatitis / Acute Liver Injury of Unknown Etiology. Rapid onset jaundice with severe transaminitis and cholestasis.

encounter.chief_complaint: New-onset overt jaundice, severe pruritus, and markedly elevated liver enzymes.
encounter.hpi:
Mr. Thorne, a 46-year-old male, presented following a visit to Urgent Care. He reports new-onset jaundice (noticed by wife 2 days ago) and intense generalized pruritus disrupting sleep. He denies abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, or fever. 

Recent History: Treated for dental abscess 3 weeks ago with Amoxicillin-Clavulanate (completed). Has been managing lingering jaw pain with Tylenol PM and Extra Strength Tylenol frequently. 

Social: Works in construction. Reports social alcohol use, denies heavy/binge drinking.

physical_exam.general: Patient is alert but clearly jaundiced (sclera and skin). Vitals stable and afebrile.
physical_exam.msk: Excoriations present on arms and legs (secondary to pruritus).
physical_exam.other_systems: Abdomen: Soft, non-tender. Liver span appears slightly enlarged on percussion (mild hepatomegaly) but is not tender to palpation. No ascites.

labs: Review of Urgent Care Labs: ALT 620 U/L, AST 450 U/L, Total Bilirubin 5.2 mg/dL, Alk Phos 188 U/L.
CBC shows Leukocytosis (11.2 K/uL) and Eosinophilia (8.5% / 0.95 abs).

management.follow_up: Urgent Referral to Hepatology (Dr. Gupta) for immediate evaluation.
management.instructions: Patient advised to stop taking all pain medications and avoid alcohol immediately as a precaution.

encounter.reason_for_visit: Urgent evaluation of jaundice and abnormal liver enzymes.

patientData.primaryDiagnosis: Severe Acute Hepatitis of Unknown Etiology

encounters.chief_complaint: Severe throbbing jaw pain and facial swelling for 2 days.
encounters.impression: Acute Dental Abscess (Right Mandibular Molar). Localized cellulitis.
encounters.notes: Diagnosed with dental abscess. Prescribed 10-day course of Augmentin and advised OTC pain relief.
encounters.casual_reason: Initial presentation of bacterial infection necessitating antibiotic therapy (Augmentin), setting the stage for potential subsequent adverse drug reaction.

encounters.impression: Antibiotic-associated Gastritis / Dyspepsia. Fatigue likely viral or post-infection.
encounters.notes: Patient reported 'washed out' feeling and nausea after finishing antibiotics. Advised rest and Tylenol PM for sleep, missing early signs of liver toxicity.
encounters.casual_reason: Prodromal symptoms of liver injury (nausea, fatigue) misattributed to antibiotic side effects or viral illness; continued analgesic use reinforced.

encounters.chief_complaint: New-onset overt jaundice and severe generalized pruritus.
encounters.impression: Severe Acute Hepatitis / Acute Liver Injury of Unknown Etiology. Rapid progression of jaundice and transaminitis.
encounters.notes: Urgent referral to Hepatology initiated. Labs reveal ALT 620 U/L, Total Bilirubin 5.2 mg/dL, and significant Eosinophilia (8.5%). Patient strictly advised to cease all pain medications and alcohol immediately.
encounters.casual_reason: Acute liver injury characterized by rapid onset jaundice, severe transaminitis (ALT 620), and Eosinophilia, occurring shortly after a dental infection, requiring urgent exclusion of viral, obstructive, or autoimmune causes.

description: This Lab Track component captures critical laboratory data from the patient's Urgent Care visit on November 19, 2025, revealing a profile of severe acute hepatocellular injury characterized by a critical elevation in ALT to 620 U/L and AST to 450 U/L. This profound enzyme elevation is accompanied by significant cholestasis, evidenced by a Total Bilirubin of 5.2 mg/dL and elevated Alkaline Phosphatase at 188 U/L, confirming the clinical presentation of overt jaundice. While synthetic liver function remains largely preserved with a borderline INR of 1.2, the hematological panel highlights a mild leukocytosis of 11.2 K/uL and a distinct eosinophilia of 8.5%, a specific finding suggesting a potential systemic hypersensitivity or allergic component to the acute liver dysfunction that requires immediate diagnostic evaluation to rule out toxic, viral, or autoimmune causes.

events.note: Diagnosed with dental abscess. Started 10-day Amoxicillin-Clavulanate.
Reported nausea/fatigue. Misdiagnosed as viral/gastritis. Analgesic use continued.
Onset of overt jaundice and severe pruritus.
Labs reveal critical transaminitis (ALT 620), hyperbilirubinemia (5.2), and eosinophilia.
Referred to Hepatology. All hepatotoxic agents (analgesics) suspended immediately.

description: Completed nurse pre-consultation assessment for Marcus Thorne - Biliary Obstruction case

transcrit.message: Hello Marcus, I'm Nurse Sarah, the urgent care sent you over today. Can you tell me a little bit about what brings you in today?
My eyes are yellow. My sister saw it two days ago. Now I look like I have a bad tan that won't go away.
I understand you're concerned about the yellow color. Can you tell me what medications you've been taking recently?
I take lisinopril for my blood pressure. I stopped taking Tylenol yesterday. I was taking a bunch of it for a toothache.

Thank you for letting me know. It's good you stopped taking the Tylenol. It's important to be aware that excessive use of acetaminophen, the medicine in Tylenol, can cause serious liver damage. Can you estimate how many extra strength or Tylenol PM pills you were taking daily over the past few weeks?
It was probably six to eight pills a day. My tooth was really throbbing. I just needed the pain to stop.
highlights: six to eight pills a day

transcrit.message: Thank you for sharing that. Since you took Augmentin for your tooth infection, have you had any nausea, vomiting, or any abdominal pain?
I've had a dull ache under my ribs, like it feels heavy. No vomiting, but I just feel nauseous all the time. I haven't been very hungry either.

I appreciate you letting me know about those symptoms. The yellowing of your eyes and skin, called jaundice, and the severe itching, can sometimes be signs of liver issues. Can you tell me when you first started noticing the yellowing and itching after you finished the Augmentin?

I finished the pills three weeks ago. The yellow started maybe two days ago. This itching, it's the worst though. It feels like there are ants under my skin, especially on my arms and chest. I can't stop scratching. I need it to stop.
That sounds really uncomfortable. It's important to know, have you had any recent travel, new sexual partners, or been exposed to anyone with hepatitis in the past few months?
No travel, no new partners. Nobody I know has hepatitis. I did have that tooth infection though. It was really bad.
Okay, thank you. Have you noticed any confusion or changes in your mental state recently?

I've been really tired, like wiped out. I had to leave work yesterday. Other than that, no. Just the pain under my ribs and all this itching. It feels like there are bugs crawling under my skin. I just need it to stop.
I see. Have you had any fevers, chills, or any flu-like symptoms in the past month?
I felt a little warm a few times, but nothing major. No chills, just this tiredness and the itching. It's really getting to me.

Thank you for letting me know about the tiredness and itching. It's important to be aware that urine that looks like Coke or stools that are white or pale can be important signs of potential liver problems. Have you noticed any changes in the color of your urine or stools since your eyes started to yellow?
My pee got really dark, like Coke. That happened three days ago. This morning my stool was pale, almost white. That's what really freaked me out.
Thank you for that information. Have you consumed any alcohol in the past month?
I have a few beers with the guys, nothing crazy. A couple nights a week.
Okay, thanks for letting me know about that. Have you had any unintentional weight loss recently?
I haven't really been eating much with the nausea and pain under my ribs. Maybe a few pounds. Mostly because I just don't want to eat.
I understand. Do you have any drug allergies?
I'm not allergic to anything. The Augmentin was fine. Just that bad toothache and all the Tylenol.
Okay. Have you had any surgeries in the past?
No surgeries. Just need this itching to stop.
I understand you're very itchy. Have you had any recent skin piercings or tattoos?
No piercings or tattoos. Just this yellow skin and the itching. It feels like I'm on fire under my skin. It's so annoying.
Thank you for providing that information. We have enough to go on for now. Goodbye.

description: Nurse clinical notes for Marcus Thorne assessment

nurseNotes.chiefComplaint: 47 y/o male presenting with jaundice and severe pruritus. Sister first noticed yellowing of eyes. Itching described as intense ('like ants crawling under skin'), rated 8-9/10, worse at night, affecting sleep.
nurseNotes.medicationHistory: Currently on lisinopril for HTN. Reports Tylenol use (6-8 pills/day x 3 weeks) for dental pain - stopped yesterday. No known drug allergies.
nurseNotes.associatedSymptoms: Dark urine ('like Coke'), pale/clay-colored stools, nausea, decreased appetite, possible unintentional weight loss (clothes looser). Dull heavy feeling under right ribs. Denies fever/chills. Social EtOH use ('few beers with the guys').
nurseNotes.pastMedicalHistory: HTN on lisinopril. Recent dental abscess. No prior liver disease. No recent travel or sick contacts.
nurseNotes.impression: Clinical picture highly suggestive of biliary obstruction. Classic triad of jaundice, pruritus, and acholic stools with choluria. Differential includes cholangitis and choledocholithiasis. RUQ discomfort supports hepatobiliary etiology.
plan: Comprehensive LFTs (AST, ALT, ALP, GGT, Bilirubin)
Abdominal ultrasound with Doppler to evaluate biliary tree
